First, it is important to understand what is meant by a dichromat. A dichromat is a person who has a color vision deficiency and can only distinguish two out of the three primary colors.

Chlorine gas appears yellow-green while neon gas appears bright orange-red. These colors fall in the range of colors that a person with normal color vision can easily distinguish from one another. However, since dichromats can only distinguish two primary colors, it is likely that they would not be able to differentiate between the two gases.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) no, a dichromat would probably not be able to easily distinguish chlorine gas from neon gas.

First, we need to understand what a dichromat is. A dichromat is a person who is color blind and can see only two primary colors. This means that they cannot distinguish between colors that are based on the third primary color.

Chlorine gas is greenish-yellow in color, while neon gas is reddish-orange in color. Since a dichromat can only see two primary colors, they will not be able to see the specific colors of the gases. Therefore, they will not be able to distinguish between the two gases based on their color.

However, the dichromat can rely on other sensory cues, such as the smell, taste, or texture of the gases, to distinguish between them. But based on color alone, a dichromat would not be able to differentiate between chlorine and neon gases. Hence, the answer to the question is (B) no.

Dichromats are individuals with a color vision deficiency in which they have only two types of functioning color receptors instead of the normal three. The two types of color receptors in dichromats are usually red-green or blue-yellow. 

Chlorine gas is a greenish-yellow gas, while neon gas emits a red-orange glow when an electrical current is passed through it. Therefore, distinguishing between these two gases would require differentiating the colors greenish-yellow and red-orange. 

Since dichromats have a deficiency in either red-green or blue-yellow color vision, it would be difficult for them to differentiate between greenish-yellow and red-orange colors. Therefore, the answer to the question is "no", a dichromat would not likely be able to easily distinguish between chlorine gas and neon gas.
